latest news.eng_title: Asian Markets Mixed As Traders Await US Data, Nvidia Release
latest news.summary: Equity investors are cautious ahead of key US data and Nvidia's earnings release, which could impact demand for artificial intelligence. Despite a potential Federal Reserve interest rate cut, traders are awaiting next week's non-farm payrolls figures. Traders remain upbeat, but attention turns to US indicators, including GDP growth, inflation, and jobless claims. Nvidia's earnings report is the headliner, with analysts warning that a disappointing result could spark a sell-off in the sector. As Ray Attrill of National Australia Bank said, 'The rebound in stock markets after the July crunch, lower gasoline prices and the heightened prospect of near-term interest rate cuts look to have overwhelmed the impact on confidence of softening labour market indicators.' Analyst Stephen Innes noted, 'This is the one that could either lift all boats or sink the entire fleet.' Asian markets were mixed, with Hong Kong, Shanghai, and Singapore dropping, while Tokyo, Wellington, and Taipei gained. Oil prices edged higher after big swings due to the Middle East crisis and Libya's decision to close fields and suspend production and exports. 'Nvidia's influence is undeniable, making it nearly impossible to take your eyes off it,' Innes added.
latest news.title: Asian Markets Mixed As Traders Await US Data, Nvidia Release

latest news.eng_title: NVIDIA to Participate in Data Centres Expo Europe 2024

Title: Vice President of Supercomputing & AI for EMEA

latest news.summary: NVIDIA, a leading company in AI computing technology, will participate in the Data Centres Expo Europe 2024, taking place on October 1-2 at the RAI in Amsterdam. Rod Evans, Vice President of Supercomputing & AI for EMEA at NVIDIA, will be the keynote speaker, sharing his insights on the transformative power of AI and supercomputing in the data center industry. The event will feature a range of speakers, including industry leaders and experts in AI technology and data centers. The agenda will cover topics such as sustainability, security, and efficiency in data centers, as well as the latest trends and innovations in the field. The Data Centres Expo Europe 2024 aims to provide a platform for knowledge sharing, networking, and collaboration among industry professionals. According to Megan Davis, Director of Techforge, the event will inspire and equip visitors with the necessary knowledge to shape the future of their sector. The event will feature keynote presentations, panel discussions, and the opportunity to interact with over 200 exhibitors showcasing products and services. 'This event is part of the TechEx Europe series, which is the leading tech event in Amsterdam,' said the source. The event is expected to attract 7,000 industry professionals and generate opportunities for collaboration and partnership.
latest news.title: NVIDIA Bestätigt Teilnahme und Wissensaustausch auf der kommenden Data Centres Expo Europe 2024

latest news.eng_title: Nvidia's Earnings Report: A Crucial Test for the Artificial Intelligence Market
latest news.summary: Nvidia, a leader in artificial intelligence, has been on a rollercoaster ride in recent months. The company's stock has surged ninefold since the end of 2022, but it has also lost nearly 30% of its value over the past seven weeks, wiping out around $800 billion in market value. As the company prepares to release its quarterly earnings on Wednesday, investors are on edge, wondering if the demand for artificial intelligence is slowing down or if one of its major cloud customers is scaling back its spending. Eric Jackson, a portfolio manager at EMJ Capital, said last week, 'It's the most important stock in the world right now.' He added, 'If they put an egg in the market, it would be a big problem for the whole market. I think they will surprise on the upside.' The company's earnings are expected to show a significant increase in revenue, with a growth rate of 112% to $28.7 billion in the fourth quarter, according to LSEG. However, the growth rate is expected to slow down in the next six quarters, making it harder to compare year-over-year results. Investors will be closely watching Nvidia's guidance for the fourth quarter, which is expected to show a growth rate of around 75% to $31.7 billion. A positive guidance could indicate that Nvidia's wealthy customers are still committed to building artificial intelligence, while a disappointing guidance could raise concerns that the spending on infrastructure has become 'optional'.
latest news.title: نجمة الذكاء الاصطناعي إنفيديا تحبس أنفاس الأسواق قبل صدور تقريرها المالي

latest news.eng_title: What Nvidia's much-anticipated earnings will tell us about the AI industry's prospects overall
latest news.summary: Nvidia's quarterly earnings report on Wednesday afternoon will provide insight into the company's future and the chip industry's financial performance. However, the results won't necessarily shed light on the broader AI industry and whether the tens of billions of dollars poured into it will ultimately pay off. Tech analyst Dan Ives of Wedbush Securities called Nvidia's upcoming report 'the most important tech earnings in years.' But Nvidia's results won't reveal much about the AI cloud providers, AI startups, and legacy businesses scrambling to make money from AI tools. The primary market for Nvidia's AI chips are companies training the biggest and most sophisticated AI models, but most companies use them for inference, which is a bigger long-term opportunity with more competition for Nvidia. Daniel Newman, principal analyst of Futurum Research, expects another one to three years of investment in AI infrastructure before the 'Walmart-like use cases' of generative AI are known. For now, there are plenty of companies starting to incorporate AI into their software and operations, but creating viable business models is 'still somewhat opaque.' Stock watchers will focus on Nvidia's shares, but many on Wall Street are wondering whether generative AI can ever really become profitable. 'It's the most important stock in the world right now,' EMJ Capital's Eric Jackson said about Nvidia last week. 'Right now, there's an industry debate raging around the (capital expenditure) requirements around generative AI,' Morgan Stanley analyst Keith Weiss said, meaning companies are spending billions on AI infrastructure, but soon expect proof that their investments are worthwhile.
latest news.title: What Nvidia's much-anticipated earnings will tell us about the AI industry's prospects overall

latest news.eng_title: Here's Why Employees At This Tech Company (Not Tesla) Won't Quit—Even When The Workday Ends At 2 Am
latest news.summary: Nvidia, a leading AI chipmaker, has an 'always on' culture where employees work seven days a week, often until 2 a.m., in a high-pressure environment. Despite the grueling hours, employees stay due to the company's lucrative compensation packages, often referred to as 'golden handcuffs.' One marketing employee described the environment as a 'pressure cooker,' with intense arguments and constant pressure to perform. However, the financial incentives tied to their roles keep them from leaving, with stock grants typically vesting over a four-year period. The low turnover rate of 2.7% in 2023 is a testament to the company's ability to retain talent, but the cost of success cannot be ignored, with burnout and health risks a significant concern. 'You can feel the burnout creeping in, but you just push through because the rewards are so high,' said one current employee.
latest news.title: Here's Why Employees At This Tech Company (Not Tesla) Won't Quit—Even When The Workday Ends At 2 Am

latest news.eng_title: Nvidia has become world's ‘most important stock,' adding pressure to upcoming earnings report
latest news.summary: Nvidia's stock has become increasingly volatile as investors await the company's upcoming earnings report. The chipmaker has been the primary beneficiary of the AI boom, with its market cap expanding by nine-fold since 2022. However, the stock has lost nearly 30% of its value over the past seven weeks. Analysts expect a fourth straight quarter of triple-digit revenue growth, but at a reduced pace of 112% to $28.7 billion. Investors will be paying close attention to Nvidia's forecast for the October quarter, which is expected to show growth of about 75% to $31.7 billion. Optimistic guidance will suggest that Nvidia's deep-pocketed clients are signaling an ongoing willingness to open their wallets for the AI buildout, while a disappointing forecast could raise concern that infrastructure spending has gotten frothy. 'It's the most important stock in the world right now,' said EMJ Capital's Eric Jackson. 'If they lay an egg, it would be a major problem for the whole market.' Nvidia's CFO Collette Kress has provided data points suggesting that cloud providers will generate $5 in revenue for every $1 spent on Nvidia chips over four years. The company is also expected to share further ROI metrics this quarter. The major question facing Nvidia is the timeline for its next-generation AI chips, dubbed Blackwell, which is facing production issues and may push big shipments back into the first quarter of 2025.
latest news.title: Nvidia has become world's ‘most important stock,' adding pressure to upcoming earnings report

latest news.eng_title: Nvidia has become world's 'most important stock,' adding pressure to upcoming earnings report
latest news.summary: Nvidia's stock has become increasingly volatile as investors await the company's upcoming earnings report. The chipmaker has been the primary beneficiary of the AI boom, with its market cap expanding ninefold since 2022. However, after reaching a record high in June, the stock lost 30% of its value over the next seven weeks. Now, it's in the midst of a rally that's pushed the stock within 6% of its all-time high. Analysts expect a fourth straight quarter of triple-digit growth, but at a reduced pace of 112% to $28.7 billion. Investors will be paying close attention to Nvidia's forecast for the October quarter, which is expected to show growth of about 75% to $31.7 billion. 'It's the most important stock in the world right now,' said EMJ Capital's Eric Jackson. 'If they lay an egg, it would be a major problem for the whole market.' Nvidia's CFO Colette Kress has provided data points suggesting that cloud providers will generate $5 in revenue for every $1 spent on Nvidia chips over four years. The company is also expected to share further ROI metrics this quarter. However, the timeline for Nvidia's next-generation AI chips, dubbed Blackwell, is uncertain, with production issues potentially pushing big shipments back into the first quarter of 2025.
latest news.title: Nvidia has become world's 'most important stock,' adding pressure to upcoming earnings report

latest news.eng_title: Nvidia in Focus: Pioneering Quarterly Earnings Expected
latest news.summary: The financial markets were affected by a series of macroeconomic developments in August, including the S&P Global Services PMI and optimistic retail sales in July. However, many indicators pointed to a positive trend. A notable highlight was the report from the Bureau of Labor Statistics on employment and wages, which made headlines. Analysts from Goldman Sachs predicted a significant job reduction from April 2023 to March 2024. Although the report's release initially garnered less attention, Federal Reserve Chairman Jay Powell's speech the following Friday in Jackson Hole, Wyoming, kept the financial world on edge. Powell's speech confirmed expectations of a relaxation of monetary policy by the Fed, which the markets had already largely priced in. Small businesses experienced a surge in stock prices as a result. This week's data on PCE inflation and the August employment report will be crucial. However, the focus will also be on corporate developments, such as those at Nvidia. Nvidia, the chip giant, will release its highly anticipated second-quarter report on Wednesday evening. Experts from Option Research & Technology Services predict an operating profit of 63 cents per share for this period, a significant increase from the 21 cents of the previous year's quarter. Nvidia is seen as an important indicator of the market's condition around artificial intelligence, whose growth has continued to boost the S&P 500. Nvidia's results and forecasts could either propel the overall market upward or dampen it with disappointing numbers. Although the company has consistently exceeded expectations in the past six quarters, there are uncertainties. Recent rumors about delays in the next generation of AI chips have cast a shadow. Despite this, investors have shown confidence, as the stock was able to recover losses by the end of the month. The semiconductor industry has undergone significant changes this year. Intel continues to struggle with market share losses and disappointed with both revenue and profit in its latest report. The company aims to counteract this with cost-cutting measures and dividend payments. This week, Intel will participate in the Deutsche Bank Technology Conference. The importance of the international market is underscored by Taiwan Semiconductor, which has become the largest publicly traded company outside the US. Although the company's full quarterly results are not expected until October, a look at the interim report in September is worthwhile. In a time when macroeconomic data influences expectations of interest rate cuts, Nvidia will be in the spotlight this week, along with Taiwan Semiconductor, as the chip industry will be closely watched.
latest news.title: Nvidia im Fokus: Wegweisende Quartalszahlen erwartet

latest news.eng_title: Missed the Nvidia and Meta Run-up? 3 More AI Stocks to Buy Before It's Too Late
latest news.summary: The recent tech stock selloff has made AI stocks like Nvidia and Meta more expensive, but there are still opportunities to invest in the industry. Bloomberg Intelligence estimates that the generative AI industry will reach $1.3 trillion by 2032. Three under-the-radar AI stocks to consider are Entergy (ETR), Deere (DE), and Cisco Systems (CSCO). Entergy can capitalize on the data center build-out in the southern US, where it operates. Deere is using AI to transform farming, and Cisco Systems is repositioning itself to capitalize on the future of AI. These stocks have lower valuations compared to their earnings and revenue, making them attractive for long-term potential. 'The Next NVIDIA' report outlines key breakthroughs in AI and the stocks ready to dominate the next wave of growth.
latest news.title: Missed the Nvidia and Meta Run-up? 3 More AI Stocks to Buy Before It's Too Late

latest news.eng_title: Nvidia's Stock: A Bellwether for the AI Trade?
latest news.summary: Nvidia's stock has risen by 157% this year and 194% in the past 12 months. Analysts are expecting the company to exceed its revenue expectations for the second quarter, with a consensus estimate of $28 billion. Morningstar's Brian Colello believes that Nvidia will continue to deliver strong results, saying 'I would be astonished if they didn't meet or exceed their expectations for the quarter and/or not raise their expectations for the October quarter.' However, he warns that if investors are disappointed with the results, it could have a ripple effect on the broader market, as Nvidia's stock is a significant component of the major indices. Colello notes that the company's revenue is driven by the increasing demand for AI infrastructure from cloud computing companies like Microsoft, Meta, and Amazon. He also highlights the risk of a potential crash in AI investments if the supply of AI GPUs becomes sufficient. Steve Sosnick, head of strategy at Interactive Brokers, agrees that the sustainability of AI spending is a concern, saying 'It's hard to imagine a company that has consistently exceeded expectations, raised expectations, and then exceeded them again.' He notes that the recent volatility in Nvidia's stock is a sign that investors are starting to question the durability of the AI trade. Colello also warns that the AI trade has been declining relative to the broader market, citing concerns about the sustainability of AI spending. He notes that the risk of a crash in AI investments is high, and that Nvidia's stock could be a bellwether for the broader market.
latest news.title: Wat als Nvidia niet aan de verwachtingen voldoet?

news knowledge.eng_title: Ranked: The Biggest Layoffs in Tech So Far in 2024
news knowledge.summary: Tech companies have been cutting jobs in the thousands this year, with Dell and Intel leading the pack. Dell is expected to cut 20,000 jobs this year, after an initial 6,000 in March, as part of an AI pivot. Intel has already cut 15,000 jobs and is struggling with operating losses and lost clients. Tesla has also cut 14,500 jobs due to slowing demand and stiff competition in China. Meanwhile, Nvidia's CEO Jensen Huang has committed to no job cuts, which may be a key reason why he is highly rated by employees. According to Layoffs.fyi, the top 10 tech companies with the most layoffs in 2024 are: Dell (26,000), Intel (15,000), Tesla (14,500), Cisco (10,150), SAP (8,000), Toshiba (4,000), Paytm (3,500), Getir (3,300), PayPal (2,585), and UKG (2,200).
news knowledge.title: Ranked: The Biggest Layoffs in Tech So Far in 2024

news knowledge.eng_title: Cisco Announces Layoffs of 6,000 Employees Amid Focus on Cybersecurity and AI
news knowledge.summary: Cisco, a leading networking company, has announced plans to lay off 6,000 employees, despite releasing better-than-expected results for its fourth quarter (May to July). According to a report, the company plans to cut its workforce by 7%, which would be the second major layoff this year. In February 2024, Cisco laid off 4,000 employees, which was 5% of its total workforce. The company aims to reduce costs by $1 billion through this move and focus on cybersecurity and AI. Cisco expects to save $700-800 million by the end of the first quarter of 2025 and the rest by the end of the year. The company has already announced investments in AI startups Cohere, Mistral, and Scale, and will work with Nvidia on AI projects. This move follows Intel's announcement of laying off 15,000 employees and Dell's announcement of laying off 12,500 employees. Other major companies like Microsoft, Amazon, and Google have also announced layoffs in recent months.
news knowledge.title: Cisco Layoffs: सिस्को 6,000 कर्मचारियों की करेगी छुट्टी, उम्मीद से बेहतर नतीजे के बावजूद बड़ा फैसला

news knowledge.eng_title: Cisco to Lay Off 6,000 Employees, Focus on Cybersecurity and AI
news knowledge.summary: Cisco, a leading networking company, is planning to lay off a large number of employees, reportedly around 6,000. This decision comes despite the company's recent better-than-expected quarterly results. According to a report in Money Control, the company is planning to reduce its workforce by 7%, which would be its second major layoff this year. In February 2024, the company had laid off 4,000 employees, which was 5% of its workforce. Cisco aims to reduce costs and focus on cybersecurity and AI by cutting expenses. The company expects to save around $1 billion in costs, which would be used to invest in AI and cybersecurity. Cisco has already invested $1 billion in AI startups Cohere, Mistral, and Scale in June 2024. The company is also partnering with Nvidia to work on AI projects. This move comes as several other tech giants, including Intel, Dell, Microsoft, and Amazon, have also announced layoffs in recent months.
news knowledge.title: सिस्को 6,000 कर्मचारियों की करेगी छुट्टी, इस कारण कंपनी ने लिया यह फैसला

news knowledge.eng_title: Intel cuts 15,000 jobs as it struggles to keep pace with NVIDIA
news knowledge.summary: Intel is cutting more than 15,000 jobs and pausing 'non-essential' projects, particularly in marketing and R&D, in an effort to revive profits and catch up with rivals such as Nvidia and AMD. The move comes after the company reported a $1.6bn loss in the April-June period. Shares in Intel fell by 20% following the announcement. Chief executive Pat Gelsinger said, 'The situation requires bolder actions and we have to fundamentally change the way we operate.' Intel previously conducted a significant round of layoffs in October 2022, but this is a new round of job cuts, with the majority expected to be completed by the end of 2024. The company's sales fell 1% year-on-year in the three months to June and it warned that the second half of the year would be worse than expected.
news knowledge.title: Intel cuts 15,000 jobs as it struggles to keep pace with NVIDIA

news knowledge.eng_title: Intel Confirms Major Round of Layoffs, Affecting Around 15,000 Jobs
news knowledge.summary: Intel has confirmed a major round of layoffs, affecting around 15,000 jobs, as part of a plan to save $10 billion in 2025. In a note to employees, CEO Pat Gelsinger said, 'We must align our cost structure with our new operating model and fundamentally change the way we operate.' He added, 'Our revenues have not grown as expected, and we have not yet fully benefited from powerful trends like AI. Our costs are too high, and our margins are too low. We need bolder actions to address both, particularly given our financial results and outlook for the second half of 2024, which is more challenging than previously expected.' Gelsinger also announced that the company will offer a improved retirement package and a voluntary leave program for eligible employees. He stated, 'These decisions have challenged me to my core, and this is the hardest thing I've done in my career.' He emphasized, 'My commitment to you is that we will prioritize a culture of honesty, transparency, and respect in the coming weeks and months.' This is the second round of layoffs at Intel since the COVID-19 pandemic, following a 5% reduction in staff in October 2022. The company is trying to recover in the market, but it is not alone in the tech industry, as other companies have also announced massive layoffs and hiring freezes in recent years.
news knowledge.title: Intel Confirms Major Round of Layoffs, Affecting Around 15,000 Jobs

news knowledge.eng_title: Intel Plans to Cut Thousands of Jobs to Reduce Costs and Regain Prominence in Semiconductor Industry
news knowledge.summary: Intel plans to cut thousands of jobs to reduce costs and finance an ambitious recovery effort after a decline in profits and market share. The company, which has around 110,000 employees, may announce the layoffs this week, according to sources familiar with the plans. CEO Pat Gelsinger is investing heavily in research and development to improve Intel's technology and help the company regain its prominence in the semiconductor industry. The company's stock rose 1.8% to $12:13 in New York on Wednesday. Other chip manufacturers, led by Nvidia, have rapidly developed profitable semiconductors for demanding tasks related to artificial intelligence. Intel is also dealing with irregular demand for chips that operate laptops and desktop computers, its main business. Gelsinger believes that Intel can improve its technology and has embarked on a plan to build factories for other chip manufacturers. The company reduced its workforce by around 5% in 2023 to 124,800 employees by the end of the year, after announcing job cuts that began in October 2022. Analysts project that Intel will report stable revenue for the second quarter compared to the previous year, with modest growth in the second half of 2024 and total sales increasing 3% to $55.7 billion for the full year, according to Wall Street estimates.
news knowledge.title: Intel planeja cortar empregos para reduzir custos - 31/07/2024 - Mercado - Folha

news knowledge.summary: Intel Corp. is planning to lay off thousands of employees to cut costs and finance new programs, according to a report from Bloomberg. The workforce reorganization could come as early as this week, affecting around 7,000 employees across its four Santa Clara locations. This move comes as the company prepares to present its second quarter earnings report on August 1, amidst a tough few years for Intel, with competitors like Nvidia Corp. leading the semiconductor and microchip industry. Despite efforts by CEO Pat Gelsinger to turn the company around through cost-cutting and manufacturing new advanced chip technologies, Intel has experienced significant losses, including $7 billion in operating losses for its new Intel Foundry in 2023. The company's revenue for 2023 was $18.9 billion, down 31% from $27.49 billion in 2022. As part of a cost-reduction plan announced in October 2022, Intel aimed to cut costs by $3 billion in 2023 by reducing its headcount to 124,800 by the end of 2023.
news knowledge.title: Major Intel workforce reorg coming

news knowledge.eng_title: Intel Plans To Reportedly Layoff At Least 10,000 Employees To Rebound From Share Losses
news knowledge.summary: Intel, with approximately 1,10,000 employees globally, is reportedly planning to lay off at least 10,000 employees as a cost-cutting measure to recover from losses, according to a Bloomberg report. The layoffs, which could begin as early as this week, are expected to save Intel up to $10 billion by 2025. This move comes as rival chipmaker Nvidia Corp. grows in the AI market, with big companies like Elon Musk's EV and AI companies collaborating with Nvidia for their AI computational needs. Intel's new AI chip, Gaudi 3, unveiled in April 2024, boasts 1.5x more speed than Nvidia's H100, used by Elon Musk's xAI in the development of Grok AI. However, Intel is ' sluggishly pivoting' in the AI market, according to the report. 'Intel expects to save up to $10 billion by 2025 with the job cuts,' said the report, citing the company's plans to recover from its losses.
news knowledge.title: Intel Plans To Reportedly Layoff At Least 10,000 Employees To Rebound From Share Losses

news knowledge.eng_title: Tech layoffs: Nvidia-backed AI startup Cohere fires 5% workforce
news knowledge.summary: Nvidia-backed AI startup Cohere has laid off approximately 5% of its workforce, citing a strategic realignment to optimize resources and focus on core competencies. Despite the job cuts, the company is actively hiring in key areas such as customer operations, partnerships, sales, and product design. A company representative stated, 'With our most recent round of financing in place, we have a clear vision for the future of Cohere, which has required some internal realignment. We will continue to aggressively hire people as we work to offer companies the most accurate, secure and private multilingual AI solutions in the market.' This move follows a trend of layoffs in the tech industry, as companies adjust to economic uncertainties and prioritize core business functions.
news knowledge.title: Tech layoffs: Nvidia-backed AI startup Cohere fires 5% workforce
